intro: Macroplectrum calceolus, commonly known as the yellow bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils and thrives in partial to full sun. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and branching. The yellow bellflower is often found in wetlands and along the edges of ponds, where it plays a role in supporting local biodiversity.
